Note:
See Whiting (1968)
XWhiting, Bartlett Jere. Proverbs, Sentences, and Proverbial Phrases from English Writings Mainly before 1500. Cambridge, MA: Belknap, 1968, G45
Bibliographic Ghosts: Oxford, Bodleian Library Rawlinson C.83 (SC 11948), f. 31: this MS has only 7 folios and does not seem to contain any verse.
_description: Speak no evil behind a friend’s back — short poem, accompanied by Latin

Bod315.Transcription:
Hit falleth to a gentil manTo say þe best þat he canOf
                    euery man in his absenceAnd say hym soth in his presence
Bod315.Note:
First four lines only; occurs with 1879, 6568, 6621.5, 6644 (the last formerly included with this; all
                    originally copied from Cornwall,  olim Launceston Priory,  a wall inscription, no longer visible).
Bod315.Editions:
Robbins,  Rossell Hope. 
             “Wall Verses at Launceston Priory.” 
             Archiv für das Studium der neueren Sprachen und
                Literaturen
         200 (1963): 338-43: 342, 353.
Sisam,  Celia,  and  Kenneth Sisam, eds.  
             The Oxford Book of Medieval English Verse.
         Oxford: Clarendon, 1970: 562.

CamTCC595.Transcription:
It falleth for every gentlemanTo saie the best that he canIn
                    mannes absenceAnd the sothe in his presenceIt cometh by kinde of
                    gentle bloddeTo cast awaie all heuynesseAnd gader togider wordes
                    goodThe werke of wisdome beareth wittnesse
CamTCC595.Note: Eight lines; immediately follows 6299 as if another stanza.
CamTCC595.Editions:
Robbins,  Rossell Hope. 
             “Wall Verses at Launceston Priory.” 
             Archiv für das Studium der neueren Sprachen und
                Literaturen
         200 (1963): 338-43: 342, 353.
Sisam,  Celia,  and  Kenneth Sisam, eds.  
             The Oxford Book of Medieval English Verse.
         Oxford: Clarendon, 1970: 562.
